greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = the least integer that is polygonal in exactly n ways.
comment: a(n) has exactly n representations as an m-gonal number P(m,r) = r*((m-2)*r-(m-4))/2, with m>2, r>1.
link: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Polygonal Number.
example: a(3) = 15 because 15 is the least integer which is polygonal in 3 ways (15 is n-gonal for n = 3, 6, 15).
maple: A063778 := proc(nmax) local a,n,ps ; a := [seq(0,i=1..nmax)] ; n := 1 ; while true do ps := A129654(n) ; if ps > 0 and ps <= nmax and n > 1 then if op(ps,a) = 0 then a := subsop(ps=n,a) ; print(a) ; fi ; fi ; n := n+1 ; end: RETURN(a) ; end: A063778(30) ; # _R. J. Mathar_, May 14 2007
program: (PARI) lista(nn) = {rec = 0; for (n=3, nn, new = sum(k=3, n, ispolygonal(n, k)); if (new > rec, rec = new; print1(n, ", ")););} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 25 2015
xref: Cf. A177025 (number of different ways to represent n as a polygonal).
Cf. A129654 (number of different ways to represent n as general polygonal).
results.author: _David W. Wilson_, Aug 16 2001
ext: Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_ at the suggestion of _Andrew S. Plewe_, May 23 2007
